books.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 1

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 1:1
verses.text: Whence the Greeks also applied the denominative appellation of wise and sophists (σοφοί, σοφισταί) to those who were versed in anything Cratinus accordingly, having in the Archilochii enumerated the poets, said:—  "Such a hive of sophists have ye examined".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 1:2
verses.text: And similarly Iophon, the comic poet, in Flute-playing Satyrs, says:—  "For there entered A band of sophists, all equipped".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 1:3
verses.text: Of these and the like, who devote their attention to empty words, the divine Scripture most excellently says, "I will destroy the wisdom of the wise, and bring to nothing the understanding of the prudent".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 2

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 2:1
verses.text: Chapter 4—Human Arts as Well as Divine Knowledge Proceed from God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 2:2
verses.text: Homer calls an artificer wise; and of Margites, if that is his work, he thus writes:—  "Him, then, the Gods made neither a delver nor a ploughman, Nor in any other respect wise; but he missed every art".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 2:3
verses.text: Hesiod further said the musician Linus was "skilled in all manner of wisdom;" and does not hesitate to call a mariner wise, seeing he writes:—  "Having no wisdom in navigation".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 2:4
verses.text: And Daniel the prophet says, "The mystery which the king asks, it is not in the power of the wise, the Magi, the diviners, the Gazarenes, to tell the king; but it is God in heaven who revealeth it".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 2:5
verses.text: Here he terms the Babylonians wise.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 2:6
verses.text: And that Scripture calls every secular science or art by the one name wisdom (there are other arts and sciences invented over and above by human reason), and that artistic and skilful invention is from God, will be clear if we adduce the following  statement: "And the Lord spake to Moses, See, I have called Bezaleel, the son of Uri, the son of Or, of the tribe of Judah; and I have filled him with the divine spirit of wisdom, and understanding, and knowledge, to devise and to execute in all manner of work, to work gold, and silver, and brass, and blue, and purple, and scarlet, and in working stone work, and in the art of working wood," and even to "all works".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 2:7
verses.text: And then He adds the general reason, "And to every understanding heart I have given understanding;" that is, to every one capable of acquiring it by pains and exercise.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 2:8
verses.text: And again, it is written expressly in the name of the Lord: "And speak thou to all that are wise in mind, whom I have filled with the spirit of perception".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 2:9
verses.text: Those who are wise in mind have a certain attribute of nature peculiar to themselves; and they who have shown themselves capable, receive from the Supreme Wisdom a spirit of perception in double measure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 2:10
verses.text: For those who practice the common arts, are in what pertains to the senses highly gifted: in hearing, he who is commonly called a musician; in touch, he who moulds clay; in voice the singer, in smell the perfumer, in sight the engraver of devices on seals.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 2:11
verses.text: Those also that are occupied in instruction, train the sensibility according to which the poets are susceptible to the influence of measure; the sophists apprehend expression; the dialecticians, syllogisms; and the philosophers are capable of the contemplation of which themselves are the objects.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 2:12
verses.text: For sensibility finds and invents; since it persuasively exhorts to application.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 2:13
verses.text: And practice will increase the application which has knowledge for its end.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 2:14
verses.text: With reason, therefore, the apostle has called the wisdom of God "manifold," and which has manifested its power "in many departments and in many modes"—by art, by knowledge, by faith, by prophecy—for our benefit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 2:15
verses.text: "For all wisdom is from the Lord, and is with Him for ever," as says the wisdom of Jesus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 2:16
verses.text: For if thou call on wisdom and knowledge with a loud voice, and seek it as treasures of silver, and eagerly track it out, thou shalt understand godliness and find divine knowledge".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 2:17
verses.text: The prophet says this in contradiction to the knowledge according to philosophy, which teaches us to investigate in a magnanimous and noble manner, for our progress in piety.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 2:18
verses.text: He opposes, therefore, to it the knowledge which is occupied with piety, when referring to knowledge, when he speaks as follows: "For God gives wisdom out of His own mouth, and knowledge along with understanding, and treasures up help for the righteous".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 2:19
verses.text: For to those who have been justified by philosophy, the knowledge which leads to piety is laid up as a help.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:1
verses.text: Chapter 5—Philosophy the Handmaid of Theology.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:2
verses.text: Accordingly, before the advent of the Lord, philosophy was necessary to the Greeks for righteousness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:3
verses.text: And now it becomes conducive to piety; being a kind of preparatory training to those who attain to faith through demonstration.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:4
verses.text: "For thy foot," it is said, "will not stumble, if thou refer what is good, whether belonging to the Greeks or to us, to Providence".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:5
verses.text: For God is the cause of all good things; but of some primarily, as of the Old and the New Testament; and of others by consequence, as philosophy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:6
verses.text: Perchance, too, philosophy was given to the Greeks directly and primarily, till the Lord should call the Greeks.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:7
verses.text: For this was a schoolmaster to bring "the Hellenic mind," as the law, the Hebrews, "to Christ".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:8
verses.text: Philosophy, therefore, was a preparation, paving the way for him who is perfected in Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:9
verses.text: "Now," says Solomon, "defend wisdom, and it will exalt thee, and it will shield thee with a crown of pleasure".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:10
verses.text: For when thou hast strengthened wisdom with a cope by philosophy, and with right expenditure, thou wilt preserve it unassailable by sophists.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:11
verses.text: The way of truth is therefore one.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:12
verses.text: But into it, as into a perennial river, streams flow from all sides.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:13
verses.text: It has been therefore said by inspiration: "Hear, my son, and receive my words; that thine may be the many ways of life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:14
verses.text: For I teach thee the ways of wisdom; that the fountains fail thee not," which gush forth from the earth itself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:15
verses.text: Not only did He enumerate several ways of salvation for any one righteous man, but He added many other ways of many righteous, speaking thus: "The paths of the righteous shine like the light".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:16
verses.text: The commandments and the modes of preparatory training are to be regarded as the ways and appliances of life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:17
verses.text: "Jerusalem, Jerusalem, how often would I have gathered thy children, as a hen her chickens!" And Jerusalem is, when interpreted, "a vision of peace".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:18
verses.text: He therefore shows prophetically, that those who peacefully contemplate sacred things are in manifold ways trained to their calling.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:19
verses.text: What then? He "would," and could not.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:20
verses.text: How often, and where? Twice; by  the prophets, and by the advent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:21
verses.text: The expression, then, "How often," shows wisdom to be manifold; every mode of quantity and quality, it by all means saves some, both in time and in eternity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:22
verses.text: "For the Spirit of the Lord fills the earth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:23
verses.text: And if any should violently say that the reference is to the Hellenic culture, when it is said, "Give not heed to an evil woman; for honey drops from the lips of a harlot," let him hear what follows: "who lubricates thy throat for the time".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:24
verses.text: But philosophy does not flatter.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:25
verses.text: Who, then, does He allude to as having committed fornication? He adds expressly, "For the feet of folly lead those who use her, after death, to Hades.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:26
verses.text: But her steps are not supported".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:27
verses.text: Therefore remove thy way far from silly pleasure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:28
verses.text: "Stand not at the doors of her house, that thou yield not thy life to others".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:29
verses.text: And He testifies, "Then shall thou repent in old age, when the flesh of thy body is consumed".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:30
verses.text: For this is the end of foolish pleasure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:31
verses.text: Such, indeed, is the case.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:32
verses.text: And when He says, "Be not much with a strange woman," He admonishes us to use indeed, but not to linger and spend time with, secular culture.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:33
verses.text: For what was bestowed on each generation advantageously, and at seasonable times, is a preliminary training for the word of the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:34
verses.text: "For already some men, ensnared by the charms of handmaidens, have despised their consort philosophy, and have grown old, some of them in music, some in geometry, others in grammar, the most in rhetoric".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:35
verses.text: "But as the encyclical branches of study contribute to philosophy, which is their mistress; so also philosophy itself co-operates for the acquisition of wisdom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:36
verses.text: For philosophy is the study of wisdom, and wisdom is the knowledge of things divine and human; and their causes".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:37
verses.text: Wisdom is therefore queen of philosophy, as philosophy is of preparatory culture.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:38
verses.text: For if philosophy "professes control of the tongue, and the belly, and the parts below the belly, it is to be chosen on its own account.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:39
verses.text: But it appears more worthy of respect and pre-eminence, if cultivated for the honour and knowledge of God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:40
verses.text: And Scripture will afford a testimony to what has been said in what follows.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:41
verses.text: Sarah was at one time barren, being Abraham's wife.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:42
verses.text: Sarah having no child, assigned her maid, by name Hagar, the Egyptian, to Abraham, in order to get children.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:43
verses.text: Wisdom, therefore, who dwells with the man of faith (and Abraham was reckoned faithful and righteous), was still barren and without child in that generation, not having brought forth to Abraham aught allied to virtue.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:44
verses.text: And she, as was proper, thought that he, being now in the time of progress, should have intercourse with secular culture first (by Egyptian the world is designated figuratively); and afterwards should approach to her according to divine providence, and beget Isaac".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:45
verses.text: And Philo interprets Hagar to mean "sojourning".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:46
verses.text: For it is said in connection with this, "Be not much with a strange woman".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:47
verses.text: Sarah he interprets to mean "my princedom".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:48
verses.text: He, then, who has received previous training is at liberty to approach to wisdom, which is supreme, from which grows up the race of Israel.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:49
verses.text: These things show that that wisdom can be acquired through instruction, to which Abraham attained, passing from the contemplation of heavenly things to the faith and righteousness which are according to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:50
verses.text: And Isaac is shown to mean "self-taught;" wherefore also he is discovered to be a type of Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:51
verses.text: He was the husband of one wife Rebecca, which they translate "Patience".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:52
verses.text: And Jacob is said to have consorted with several, his name being interpreted "Exerciser".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:53
verses.text: And exercises are engaged in by means of many and various dogmas.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:54
verses.text: Whence, also, he who is really "endowed with the power of seeing" is called Israel, having much experience, and being fit for exercise.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:55
verses.text: Something else may also have been shown by the three patriarchs, namely, that the sure seal of knowledge is composed of nature, of education, and exercise.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:56
verses.text: You may have also another image of what has been said, in Thamar sitting by the way, and presenting the appearance of a harlot, on whom the studious Judas (whose name is interpreted "powerful"), who left nothing unexamined and uninvestigated, looked; and turned aside to her, preserving his profession towards God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:57
verses.text: Wherefore also, when Sarah was jealous at Hagar being preferred to her, Abraham, as choosing only what was profitable in secular philosophy, said, "Behold, thy maid is in thine hands: deal with her as it pleases thee;" manifestly meaning, "I embrace secular culture as youthful, and a handmaid; but thy knowledge I honour and reverence as true wife".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:58
verses.text: And Sarah afflicted her; which is equivalent to corrected and admonished her.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:59
verses.text: It has therefore been well said, "My son, despise not thou the correction of God; nor faint when thou art rebuked of Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:60
verses.text: For whom the Lord loveth He chasteneth, and scourgeth every son whom He receiveth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:61
verses.text: And the foresaid Scriptures, when examined in other places, will be seen to exhibit other mysteries.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 3:62
verses.text: We merely therefore assert here, that philosophy is characterized by investigation into truth and the nature of things (this is the truth of which the Lord Himself said, "I am the truth"); and that, again, the preparatory training for rest in Christ exercises the mind, rouses the intelligence, and begets an inquiring shrewdness, by means of the true philosophy, which the initiated possess, having found it, or rather received it, from the truth itself.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4:1
verses.text: Chapter 6—The Benefit of Culture.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4:2
verses.text: The readiness acquired by previous training conduces much to the perception of such things as are requisite; but those things which can be perceived only by mind are the special exercise for the mind.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4:3
verses.text: And their nature is triple according as we consider their quantity, their magnitude, and what can be predicated of them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4:4
verses.text: For the discourse which consists of demonstrations, implants in the spirit of him who follows it, clear faith; so that he cannot conceive of that which is demonstrated being different; and so it does not allow us to succumb to those who assail us by fraud.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4:5
verses.text: In such studies, therefore, the soul is purged from sensible things, and is excited, so as to be able to see truth distinctly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4:6
verses.text: For nutriment, and the training which is maintained gentle, make noble natures; and noble natures, when they have received such training, become still better than before both in other respects, but especially in productiveness, as is the case with the other creatures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4:7
verses.text: Wherefore it is said, "Go to the ant, thou sluggard, and become wiser than it, which provideth much and, varied food in the harvest against the inclemency of winter".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4:8
verses.text: Or go to the bee, and learn how laborious she is; for she, feeding on the whole meadow, produces one honey-comb.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4:9
verses.text: And if "thou prayest in the closet," as the Lord taught, "to worship in spirit," thy management will no longer be solely occupied about the house, but also about the soul, what must be bestowed on it, and how, and how much; and what must be laid aside and treasured up in it; and when it ought to be produced, and to whom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4:10
verses.text: For it is not by nature, but by learning, that people become noble and good, as people also become physicians and pilots.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4:11
verses.text: We all in common, for example, see the vine and the horse.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4:12
verses.text: But the husbandman will know if the vine be good or bad at fruit-bearing; and the horseman will easily distinguish between the spiritless and the swift animal.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4:13
verses.text: But that some are naturally predisposed to virtue above others, certain pursuits of those, who are so naturally predisposed above others, show.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4:14
verses.text: But that perfection in virtue is not the exclusive property of those, whose natures are better, is proved, since also those who by nature are ill-disposed towards virtue, in obtaining suitable training, for the most part attain to excellence; and, on the other hand, those whose natural dispositions are apt, become evil through neglect.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4:15
verses.text: Again, God has created us naturally social and just; whence justice must not be said to take its rise from implantation alone.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4:16
verses.text: But the good imparted by creation is to be conceived of as excited by the commandment; the soul being trained to be willing to select what is noblest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4:17
verses.text: But as we say that a man can be a believer without learning, so also we assert that it is impossible for a man without learning to comprehend the things which are declared in the faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4:18
verses.text: But to adopt what is well said, and not to adopt the reverse, is caused not simply by faith, but by faith combined with knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4:19
verses.text: But if ignorance is want of training and of instruction, then teaching produces knowledge of divine and human things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4:20
verses.text: But just as it is possible to live rightly in penury of this world's good things, so also in abundance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4:21
verses.text: And we avow, that at once with more ease and more speed will one attain to virtue through previous training.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4:22
verses.text: But it is not such as to be unattainable without it; but it is attainable only when they have learned, and have had their senses exercised.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4:23
verses.text: "For hatred," says Solomon, "raises strife, but instruction guardeth the ways of life;" in such a way that we are not deceived nor deluded by those who are practiced in base arts for the injury of those who hear.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4:24
verses.text: "But instruction wanders reproachless," it is said.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4:25
verses.text: We must be conversant with the art of reasoning, for the purpose of confuting the deceitful opinions of the sophists.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4:26
verses.text: Well and felicitously, therefore, does Anaxarchus write in his book respecting "kingly rule:" "Erudition benefits greatly and hurts greatly him who possesses it; it helps him who is worthy, and injures him who utters readily every word, and before the whole people.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4:27
verses.text: It is necessary to know the measure of time.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4:28
verses.text: For this is the end of wisdom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4:29
verses.text: And those who sing at the doors, even if they sing skilfully, are not reckoned wise, but have the reputation of folly".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4:30
verses.text: And Hesiod:—  "Of the Muses, who make a man loquacious, divine, vocal".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 4:31
verses.text: For him who is fluent in words he calls loquacious; and him who is clever, vocal; and "divine," him who is skilled, a philosopher, and acquainted with the truth.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 5

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 5:1
verses.text: Chapter 7—The Eclectic Philosophy Paves the Way for Divine Virtue.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 5:2
verses.text: The Greek preparatory culture, therefore, with philosophy itself, is shown to have come down from God to men, not with a definite direction but in the way in which showers fall down on the good land, and on the dunghill, and on the houses.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 5:3
verses.text: And similarly both the grass and the wheat sprout; and the figs and any other reckless trees grow on sepulchres.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 5:4
verses.text: And things that grow, appear as a type of truths.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 5:5
verses.text: For they enjoy the same influence of the rain.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 5:6
verses.text: But they have not the same grace as those which spring up in rich soil, inasmuch as they are withered or plucked up.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 5:7
verses.text: And here we are aided by the parable of the sower, which the Lord interpreted.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 5:8
verses.text: For the husbandman of the soil which is among men is one; He who from the beginning, from the foundation of the world, sowed nutritious seeds; He who in each age rained down the Lord, the Word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 5:9
verses.text: But the times and places which received such gifts, created the differences which exist.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 5:10
verses.text: Further, the husbandman sows not only wheat (of which there are many varieties), but also other seeds—barley, and beans, and peas, and vetches, and vegetable and flower seeds.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 5:11
verses.text: And to the same husbandry belongs both planting and the operations necessary in the nurseries, and gardens, and orchards, and the planning and rearing of all sorts of trees.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 5:12
verses.text: In like manner, not only the care of sheep, but the care of herds, and breeding of horses, and dogs, and bee-craft, all arts, and to speak comprehensively, the care of flocks and the rearing of animals, differ from each other more or less, but are all useful for life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 5:13
verses.text: And philosophy—I do not mean the Stoic, or the Platonic, or the Epicurean, or the Aristotelian, but whatever has been well said by each of those sects, which teach righteousness along with a science pervaded by piety,—this eclectic whole I call philosophy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 5:14
verses.text: But such conclusions of human reasonings, as men have cut away and falsified, I would never call divine.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 5:15
verses.text: And now we must look also at this, that if ever those who know not how to do well, live well; for they have lighted on well-doing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 5:16
verses.text: Some, too, have aimed well at the word of truth through understanding.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 5:17
verses.text: "But Abraham was not justified by works, but by faith".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 5:18
verses.text: It is therefore of no advantage to them after the end of life, even if they do good works now, if they have not faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 5:19
verses.text: Wherefore also the Scriptures were translated into the language of the Greeks, in order that they might never be able to allege the excuse of ignorance, inasmuch as they are able to hear also what we have in our hands, if they only wish.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 5:20
verses.text: One speaks in one way of the truth, in another way the truth interprets itself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 5:21
verses.text: The guessing at truth is one thing, and truth itself is another.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 5:22
verses.text: Resemblance is one thing, the thing itself is another.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 5:23
verses.text: And the one results from learning and practice, the other from power and faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 5:24
verses.text: For the teaching of piety is a gift, but faith is grace.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 5:25
verses.text: "For by doing the will of God we know the will of God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 5:26
verses.text: "Open, then," says the Scripture, "the gates of righteousness; and I will enter in, and confess to the Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 5:27
verses.text: But the paths to righteousness (since God saves in many ways, for He is good) are many and various, and lead to the Lord's way and gate.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 5:28
verses.text: And if you ask the royal and true entrance, you will hear, "This is the gate of the Lord, the righteous shall enter in by it".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 5:29
verses.text: While there are many gates open, that in righteousness is in Christ, by which all the blessed enter, and direct their steps in the sanctity of knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 5:30
verses.text: Now Clemens, in his Epistle to the Corinthians, while expounding the differences of those who are approved according to the Church, says expressly, "One may be a believer; one may be powerful in uttering knowledge; one may be wise in discriminating between words; one may be terrible in deeds".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:1
verses.text: Chapter 8—The Sophistical Arts Useless.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:2
verses.text: But the art of sophistry, which the Greeks cultivated, is a fantastic power, which makes false opinions like true by means of words.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:3
verses.text: For it produces rhetoric in order to persuasion, and disputation for wrangling.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:4
verses.text: These arts, therefore, if not conjoined with philosophy, will be injurious to every one.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:5
verses.text: For Plato openly called sophistry "an evil art".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:6
verses.text: And Aristotle, following him, demonstrates it to be a dishonest art, which abstracts in a specious manner the whole business of wisdom, and professes a wisdom which it has not studied.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:7
verses.text: To speak briefly, as the beginning of rhetoric is the probable, and an attempted proof the process, and the end persuasion, so the beginning of disputation is what is matter of opinion, and the process a contest, and the end victory.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:8
verses.text: For in the same manner, also, the beginning of sophistry is the apparent, and the process twofold; one of rhetoric, continuous and exhaustive; and the other of logic, and is interrogatory.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:9
verses.text: And its end is admiration.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:10
verses.text: The dialectic in vogue in the schools, on the other hand, is the exercise of a philosopher in matters of opinion, for the sake of the faculty of disputation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:11
verses.text: But truth is not in these at all.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:12
verses.text: With reason, therefore, the noble apostle, depreciating these superfluous arts occupied about words, says, "If any man do not give heed to wholesome words, but is puffed up by a kind of teaching, knowing nothing, but doting (νοσῶν) about questions and strifes of words, whereof cometh contention, envy, railings, evil surmisings, perverse disputings of men of corrupt minds, destitute of the truth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:13
verses.text: You see how he is moved against them, calling their art of logic—on which, those to whom this garrulous mischievous art is dear, whether Greeks or barbarians, plume themselves—a disease (νοσος).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:14
verses.text: Very beautifully, therefore, the tragic poet Euripides says in the Phoenissae,—  "But a wrongful speech Is diseased in itself, and needs skilful medicines".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:15
verses.text: For the saving Word is called "wholesome," He being the truth; and what is wholesome (healthful) remains ever deathless.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:16
verses.text: But separation from what is healthful and divine is impiety, and a deadly malady.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:17
verses.text: These are rapacious wolves hid in sheep-skins, men-stealers, and glozing soul-seducers, secretly, but proved to be robbers; striving by fraud and force to catch us who are unsophisticated and have less power of speech.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:18
verses.text: "Often a man, impeded through want of words, carries less weight In expressing what is right, than the man of eloquence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:19
verses.text: But now in fluent mouths the weightiest truths They disguise, so that they do not seem what they ought to seem,"  says the tragedy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:20
verses.text: Such are these wranglers, whether they follow the sects, or practice miserable dialectic arts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:21
verses.text: These are they that "stretch the warp and weave nothing," says the Scripture; prosecuting a bootless task, which the apostle has called "cunning craftiness of men whereby they lie in wait to deceive".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:22
verses.text: "For there are," he says, "many unruly and vain talkers and deceivers".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:23
verses.text: Wherefore it was not said to all, "Ye are the salt of the earth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:24
verses.text: For there are some even of the hearers of the word who are like the fishes of the sea, which, reared from their birth in brine, yet need salt to dress them for food.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:25
verses.text: Accordingly I wholly approve of the tragedy, when it says:—  "O son, false words can be well spoken, And truth may be vanquished by beauty of words.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:26
verses.text: But this is not what is most correct, but nature and what is right; He who practices eloquence is indeed wise, But I consider deeds always better than words".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:27
verses.text: We must not, then, aspire to please the multitude.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:28
verses.text: For we do not practice what will please them, but what we know is remote from their disposition.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:29
verses.text: "Let us not be desirous of vainglory," says the apostle, "provoking one another, envying one another".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:30
verses.text: Thus the truth-loving Plato says, as if divinely inspired, "Since I am such as to obey nothing but the word, which, after reflection, appears to me the best".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:31
verses.text: Accordingly he charges those who credit opinions without intelligence and knowledge, with abandoning right and sound reason unwarrantably, and believing him who is a partner in falsehood.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:32
verses.text: For to cheat one's self of the truth is bad; but to speak the truth, and to hold as our opinions positive realities, is good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:33
verses.text: Men are deprived of what is good unwillingly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:34
verses.text: Nevertheless they are deprived either by being deceived or beguiled, or by being compelled and not believing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:35
verses.text: He who believes not, has already made himself a willing captive; and he who changes his persuasion is cozened, while he forgets that time imperceptibly takes away some things, and reason others.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:36
verses.text: And after an opinion has been entertained, pain and anguish, and on the other hand contentiousness and anger, compel.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:37
verses.text: Above all, men are beguiled who are either bewitched by pleasure or terrified by fear.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 6:38
verses.text: And all these are voluntary changes, but by none of these will knowledge ever be attained.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 7

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 7:1
verses.text: Chapter 9—Human Knowledge Necessary for the Understanding of the Scriptures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 7:2
verses.text: Some, who think themselves naturally gifted, do not wish to touch either philosophy or logic; nay more, they do not wish to learn natural science.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 7:3
verses.text: They demand bare faith alone, as if they wished, without bestowing any care on the vine, straightway to gather clusters from the first.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 7:4
verses.text: Now the Lord is figuratively described as the vine, from which, with pains and the art of husbandry, according to the word, the fruit is to be gathered.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 7:5
verses.text: We must lop, dig, bind, and perform the other operations.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 7:6
verses.text: The pruning-knife, I should think, and the pick-axe, and the other agricultural implements, are necessary for the culture of the vine, so that it may produce eatable fruit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 7:7
verses.text: And as in husbandry, so also in medicine: he has learned to purpose, who has practiced the various lessons, so as to be able to cultivate and to heal.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 7:8
verses.text: So also here, I call him truly learned who brings everything to bear on the truth; so that, from geometry, and music, and grammar, and philosophy itself, culling what is useful, he guards the faith against assault.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 7:9
verses.text: Now, as was said, the athlete is despised who is not furnished for the contest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 7:10
verses.text: For instance, too, we praise the experienced helmsman who "has seen the cities of many men," and the physician who has had large experience; thus also some describe the empiric.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 7:11
verses.text: And he who brings everything to bear on a right life, procuring examples from the Greeks and barbarians, this man is an experienced searcher after truth, and in reality a man of much counsel, like the touch-stone (that is, the Lydian), which is believed to possess the power of distinguishing the spurious from the genuine gold.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 7:12
verses.text: And our much-knowing gnostic can distinguish sophistry from philosophy, the art of decoration from gymnastics, cookery from physic, and rhetoric from dialectics, and the other sects which are according to the barbarian philosophy, from the truth itself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 7:13
verses.text: And how necessary is it for him who desires to be partaker of the power of God, to treat of intellectual subjects by philosophising! And how serviceable is it to distinguish expressions which are ambiguous, and which in the Testaments are used synonymously! For the Lord, at the time of His temptation, skilfully matched the devil by an ambiguous expression.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 7:14
verses.text: And I do not yet, in this connection, see how in the world the inventor of philosophy and dialectics, as some suppose, is seduced through being deceived by the form of speech which consists in ambiguity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 7:15
verses.text: And if the prophets and apostles knew not the arts by which the exercises of philosophy are exhibited, yet the mind of the prophetic and instructive spirit, uttered secretly, because all have not an intelligent ear, demands skilful modes of teaching in order to clear exposition.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 7:16
verses.text: For the prophets and disciples of the Spirit knew infallibly their mind.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 7:17
verses.text: For they knew it by faith, in a way which others could not easily, as the Spirit has said.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 7:18
verses.text: But it is not possible for those who have not learned to receive it thus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 7:19
verses.text: "Write," it is said, "the commandments doubly, in counsel and knowledge, that thou mayest answer the words of truth to them who send unto thee".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 7:20
verses.text: What, then, is the knowledge of answering? or what that of asking? It is dialectics.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 7:21
verses.text: What then? Is not speaking our business, and does not action proceed from the Word? For if we act not for the Word, we shall act against reason.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 7:22
verses.text: But a rational work is accomplished through God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 7:23
verses.text: "And nothing," it is said, "was made without Him"—the Word of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 7:24
verses.text: And did not the Lord make all things by the Word? Even the beasts work, driven by compelling fear.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 7:25
verses.text: And do not those who are called orthodox apply themselves to good works, knowing not what they do?.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:1
verses.text: Chapter 10—To Act Well of Greater Consequence Than to Speak Well.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:2
verses.text: Wherefore the Saviour, taking the bread, first spake and blessed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:3
verses.text: Then breaking the bread, He presented it, that we might eat it, according to reason, and that knowing the Scriptures we might walk obediently.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:4
verses.text: And as those whose speech is evil are no better than those whose practice is evil (for calumny is the servant of the sword, and evil-speaking inflicts pain; and from these proceed disasters in life, such being the effects of evil speech); so also those who are given to good speech are near neighbours to those who accomplish good deeds.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:5
verses.text: Accordingly discourse refreshes the soul and entices it to nobleness; and happy is he who has the use of both his hands.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:6
verses.text: Neither, therefore, is he who can act well to be vilified by him who is able to speak well; nor is he who is able to speak well to be disparaged by him who is capable of acting well.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:7
verses.text: But let each do that for which he is naturally fitted.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:8
verses.text: What the one exhibits as actually done, the other speaks, preparing, as it were, the way for well-doing, and leading the hearers to the practice of good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:9
verses.text: For there is a saving word, as there is a saving work.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:10
verses.text: Righteousness, accordingly, is not constituted without discourse.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:11
verses.text: And as the receiving of good is abolished if we abolish the doing of good; so obedience and faith are abolished when neither the command, nor one to expound the command, is taken along with us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:12
verses.text: But now we are benefited mutually and reciprocally by words and deeds; but we must repudiate entirely the art of wrangling and sophistry, since these sentences of the sophists not only bewitch and beguile the many, but sometimes by violence win a Cadmean victory.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:13
verses.text: For true above all is that Psalm, "The just shall live to the end, for he shall not see corruption, when he beholds the wise dying".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:14
verses.text: And whom does he call wise? Hear from the Wisdom of Jesus: "Wisdom is not the knowledge of evil".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:15
verses.text: Such he calls what the arts of speaking and of discussing have invented.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:16
verses.text: "Thou shalt therefore seek wisdom among the wicked, and shalt not find it".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:17
verses.text: And if you inquire again of what sort this is, you are told, "The mouth of the righteous man will distil wisdom".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:18
verses.text: And similarly with truth, the art of sophistry is called wisdom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:19
verses.text: But it is my purpose, as I reckon, and not without reason, to live according to the Word, and to understand what is revealed; but never affecting eloquence, to be content merely with indicating my meaning.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:20
verses.text: And by what term that which I wish to present is shown, I care not.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:21
verses.text: For I well know that to be saved, and to aid those who desire to be saved, is the best thing, and not to compose paltry sentences like gewgaws.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:22
verses.text: "And if," says the Pythagorean in the Politicus of Plato, "you guard against solicitude about terms, you will be richer in wisdom against old age".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:23
verses.text: And in the Theoetetus you will find again, "And carelessness about names, and expressions, and the want of nice scrutiny, is not vulgar and illiberal for the most part, but rather the reverse of this, and is sometimes necessary".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:24
verses.text: This the Scripture has expressed with the greatest possible brevity, when it said, "Be not occupied much about words".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:25
verses.text: For expression is like the dress on the body.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:26
verses.text: The matter is the flesh and sinews.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:27
verses.text: We must not therefore care more for the dress than the safety of the body.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:28
verses.text: For not only a simple mode of life, but also a style of speech devoid of superfluity and nicety, must be cultivated by him who has adopted the true life, if we are to abandon luxury as treacherous and profligate, as the ancient Lacedaemonians adjured ointment and purple, deeming and calling them rightly treacherous garments and treacherous unguents; since neither is that mode of preparing food right where there is more of seasoning than of nutriment; nor is that style of speech elegant which can please rather than benefit the hearers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:29
verses.text: Pythagoras exhorts us to consider the Muses more pleasant than the Sirens, teaching us to cultivate wisdom apart from pleasure, and exposing the other mode of attracting the soul as deceptive.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:30
verses.text: For sailing past the Sirens one man has sufficient strength, and for answering the Sphinx another one, or, if you please, not even one.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:31
verses.text: We ought never, then, out of desire for vainglory, to make broad the phylacteries.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:32
verses.text: It suffices the gnostic if only one hearer is found for him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:33
verses.text: You may hear therefore Pindar the Boeotian, who writes, "Divulge not before all the ancient speech.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:34
verses.text: The way of silence is sometimes the surest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:35
verses.text: And the mightiest word is a spur to the fight".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 8:36
verses.text: Accordingly, the blessed apostle very appropriately and urgently exhorts us "not to strive about words to no profit, but to the subverting of the hearers, but to shun profane and vain babblings, for they increase unto more ungodliness, and their word will eat as doth a canker".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:1
verses.text: Chapter 11—What is the Philosophy Which the Apostle Bids Us Shun?  This, then, "the wisdom of the world is foolishness with God," and of those who are "the wise the Lord knoweth their thoughts that they are vain".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:2
verses.text: Let no man therefore glory on account of pre-eminence in human thought.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:3
verses.text: For it is written well in Jeremiah, "Let not the wise man glory in his wisdom, and let not the mighty man glory in his might, and let not the rich man glory in his riches: but let him that glorieth glory in this, that he understandeth and knoweth that I am the Lord, that executeth mercy and judgment and righteousness upon the earth: for in these things is my delight, saith the Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:4
verses.text: "That we should trust not in ourselves, but in God who raiseth the dead," says the apostle, "who delivered us from so great a death, that our faith should not stand in the wisdom of men, but in the power of God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:5
verses.text: "For the spiritual man judgeth all things, but he himself is judged of no man".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:6
verses.text: I hear also those words of his, "And these things I say, lest any man should beguile you with enticing words, or one should enter in to spoil you".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:7
verses.text: And again, "Beware lest any man spoil you through philosophy and vain deceit, after the tradition of men, after the rudiments of the world, and not after Christ;" branding not all philosophy, but the Epicurean, which Paul mentions in the Acts of the Apostles, which abolishes providence and deifies pleasure, and whatever other philosophy honours the elements, but places not over them the efficient cause, nor apprehends the Creator.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:8
verses.text: The Stoics also, whom he mentions too, say not well that the Deity, being a body, pervades the vilest matter.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:9
verses.text: He calls the jugglery of logic "the tradition of men".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:10
verses.text: Wherefore also he adds, "Avoid juvenile questions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:11
verses.text: For such contentions are puerile".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:12
verses.text: "But virtue is no lover of boys," says the philosopher Plato.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:13
verses.text: And our struggle, according to Gorgias Leontinus, requires two virtues—boldness and wisdom,—boldness to undergo danger, and wisdom to understand the enigma.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:14
verses.text: For the Word, like the Olympian  proclamation, calls him who is willing, and crowns him who is able to continue unmoved as far as the truth is concerned.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:15
verses.text: And, in truth, the Word does not wish him who has believed to be idle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:16
verses.text: For He says, "Seek, and ye shall find".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:17
verses.text: But seeking ends in finding, driving out the empty trifling, and approving of the contemplation which confirms our faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:18
verses.text: "And this I say, lest any man beguile you with enticing words," says the apostle, evidently as having learned to distinguish what was said by him, and as being taught to meet objections.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:19
verses.text: "As ye have therefore received Christ Jesus the Lord, so walk in Him, rooted and built up in Him, and stablished in the faith".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:20
verses.text: Now persuasion is the means of being established in the faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:21
verses.text: "Beware lest any man spoil you of faith in Christ by philosophy and vain deceit," which does away with providence, "after the tradition of men;" for the philosophy which is in accordance with divine tradition establishes and confirms providence, which, being done away with, the economy of the Saviour appears a myth, while we are influenced "after the elements of the world, and not after Christ".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:22
verses.text: For the teaching which is agreeable to Christ deifies the Creator, and traces providence in particular events, and knows the nature of the elements to be capable of change and production, and teaches that we ought to aim at rising up to the power which assimilates to God, and to prefer the dispensation as holding the first rank and superior to all training.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:23
verses.text: The elements are worshipped,—the air by Diogenes, the water by Thales, the fire by Hippasus; and by those who suppose atoms to be the first principles of things, arrogating the name of philosophers, being wretched creatures devoted to pleasure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:24
verses.text: "Wherefore I pray," says the apostle, "that your love may abound yet more and more, in knowledge and in all judgment, that ye may approve things that are excellent".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:25
verses.text: "Since, when we were children," says the same apostle, "we were kept in bondage under the rudiments of the world.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:26
verses.text: And the child, though heir, differeth nothing from a servant, till the time appointed of the father".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:27
verses.text: Philosophers, then, are children, unless they have been made men by Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:28
verses.text: "For if the son of the bond woman shall not be heir with the son of the free," at least he is the seed of Abraham, though not of promise, receiving what belongs to him by free gift.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:29
verses.text: "But strong meat belongeth to those that are of full age, even those who by reason of use have their senses exercised to discern both good and evil".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:30
verses.text: "For every one that useth milk is unskilful in the word of righteousness; for he is a babe," and not yet acquainted with the word, according to which he has believed and works, and not able to give a reason in himself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:31
verses.text: "Prove all things," the apostle says, "and hold fast that which is good," speaking to spiritual men, who judge what is said according to truth, whether it seems or truly holds by the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:32
verses.text: "He who is not corrected by discipline errs, and stripes and reproofs give the discipline of wisdom," the reproofs manifestly that are with love.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:33
verses.text: "For the right heart seeketh knowledge".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:34
verses.text: "For he that seeketh the Lord shall find knowledge with righteousness; and they who have sought it rightly have found peace".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:35
verses.text: "And I will know," it is said, "not the speech of those which are puffed up, but the power".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:36
verses.text: In rebuke of those who are wise in appearance, and think themselves wise, but are not in reality wise, he writes: "For the kingdom of God is not in word".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:37
verses.text: It is not in that which is not true, but which is only probable according to opinion; but he said "in power," for the truth alone is powerful.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:38
verses.text: And again: "If any man thinketh that he knoweth anything, he knoweth nothing yet as he ought to know".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:39
verses.text: For truth is never mere opinion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:40
verses.text: But the "supposition of knowledge inflates," and fills with pride; "but charity edifieth," which deals not in supposition, but in truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 9:41
verses.text: Whence it is said, "If any man loves, he is known".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 10

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 10:1
verses.text: Chapter 12—The Mysteries of the Faith Not to Be Divulged to All.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 10:2
verses.text: But since this tradition is not published alone for him who perceives the magnificence of the word; it is requisite, therefore, to hide in a mystery the wisdom spoken, which the Son of God taught.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 10:3
verses.text: Now, therefore, Isaiah the prophet has his tongue purified by fire, so that he may be able to tell the vision.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 10:4
verses.text: And we must purify not the tongue alone, but also the ears, if we attempt to be partakers of the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 10:5
verses.text: Such were the impediments in the way of my writing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 10:6
verses.text: And even now I fear, as it is said, "to cast the pearls before swine, lest they tread them under foot, and turn and rend us".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 10:7
verses.text: For it is difficult to exhibit the really pure and transparent words respecting the true light, to swinish and untrained hearers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 10:8
verses.text: For scarcely could anything which they could hear be more ludicrous than these to the multitude; nor any subjects  on the other hand more admirable or more inspiring to those of noble nature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 10:9
verses.text: "But the natural man receiveth not the things of the Spirit of God; for they are foolishness to him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 10:10
verses.text: But the wise do not utter with their mouth what they reason in council.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 10:11
verses.text: "But what ye hear in the ear," says the Lord, "proclaim upon the houses;" bidding them receive the secret traditions of the true knowledge, and expound them aloft and conspicuously; and as we have heard in the ear, so to deliver them to whom it is requisite; but not enjoining us to communicate to all without distinction, what is said to them in parables.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 10:12
verses.text: But there is only a delineation in the memoranda, which have the truth sowed sparse and broadcast, that it may escape the notice of those who pick up seeds like jackdaws; but when they find a good husbandman, each one of them will germinate and produce corn.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 11

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 11:1
verses.text: Chapter 13—All Sects of Philosophy Contain a Germ of Truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 11:2
verses.text: Since, therefore, truth is one (for falsehood has ten thousand by-paths); just as the Bacchantes tore asunder the limbs of Pentheus, so the sects both of barbarian and Hellenic philosophy have done with truth, and each vaunts as the whole truth the portion which has fallen to its lot.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 11:3
verses.text: But all, in my opinion, are illuminated by the dawn of Light.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 11:4
verses.text: Let all, therefore, both Greeks and barbarians, who have aspired after the truth,—both those who possess not a little, and those who have any portion,—produce whatever they have of the word of truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 11:5
verses.text: Eternity, for instance, presents in an instant the future and the present, also the past of time.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 11:6
verses.text: But truth, much more powerful than limitless duration, can collect its proper germs, though they have fallen on foreign soil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 11:7
verses.text: For we shall find that very many of the dogmas that are held by such sects as have not become utterly senseless, and are not cut out from the order of nature (by cutting off Christ, as the women of the fable dismembered the man), though appearing unlike one another, correspond in their origin and with the truth as a whole.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 11:8
verses.text: For they coincide in one, either as a part, or a species, or a genus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 11:9
verses.text: For instance, though the highest note is different from the lowest note, yet both compose one harmony.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 11:10
verses.text: And in numbers an even number differs from an odd number; but both suit in arithmetic; as also is the case with figure, the circle, and the triangle, and the square, and whatever figures differ from one another.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 11:11
verses.text: Also, in the whole universe, all the parts, though differing one from another, preserve their relation to the whole.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 11:12
verses.text: So, then, the barbarian and Hellenic philosophy has torn off a fragment of eternal truth not from the mythology of Dionysus, but from the theology of the ever-living Word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 11:13
verses.text: And He who brings again together the separate fragments, and makes them one, will without peril, be assured, contemplate the perfect Word, the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 11:14
verses.text: Therefore it is written in Ecclesiastes: "And I added wisdom above all who were before me in Jerusalem; and my heart saw many things; and besides, I knew wisdom and knowledge, parables and understanding.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 11:15
verses.text: And this also is the choice of the spirit, because in abundance of wisdom is abundance of knowledge".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 11:16
verses.text: He who is conversant with all kinds of wisdom, will be pre-eminently a gnostic.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 11:17
verses.text: Now it is written, "Abundance of the knowledge of wisdom will give life to him who is of it".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 11:18
verses.text: And again, what is said is confirmed more clearly by this saying, "All things are in the sight of those who understand"—all things, both Hellenic and barbarian; but the one or the other is not all.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 11:19
verses.text: "They are right to those who wish to receive understanding.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 11:20
verses.text: Choose instruction, and not silver, and knowledge above tested gold," and prefer also sense to pure gold; "for wisdom is better than precious stones, and no precious thing is worth it".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:1
verses.text: Chapter 14—Succession of Philosophers in Greece.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:2
verses.text: The Greeks say, that after Orpheus and Linus, and the most ancient of the poets that appeared among them, the seven, called wise, were the first that were admired for their wisdom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:3
verses.text: Of whom four were of Asia—Thales of Miletus, and Bias of Priene, Pittacus of Mitylene, and Cleobulus of Lindos; and two of Europe, Solon the Athenian, and Chilon the Lacedaemonian; and the seventh, some say, was Periander of Corinth; others, Anacharsis the Scythian; others, Epimenides the Cretan, whom Paul knew as a Greek prophet, whom he mentions in the Epistle to Titus, where he speaks thus: "One of themselves, a prophet of their own, said, The Cretans are always liars, evil beasts, slow bellies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:4
verses.text: And this witness is true".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:5
verses.text: You see how even to the prophets of the Greeks he attributes something of the truth, and is not ashamed, when discoursing  for the edification of some and the shaming of others, to make use of Greek poems.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:6
verses.text: Accordingly to the Corinthians (for this is not the only instance), while discoursing on the resurrection of the dead, he makes use of a tragic Iambic line, when he said, "What advantageth it me if the dead are not raised? Let us eat and drink, for to-morrow we die.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:7
verses.text: Be not deceived; evil communications corrupt good manners".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:8
verses.text: Others have enumerated Acusilaus the Argive among the seven wise men; and others, Pherecydes of Syros.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:9
verses.text: And Plato substitutes Myso the Chenian for Periander, whom he deemed unworthy of wisdom, on account of his having reigned as a tyrant.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:10
verses.text: That the wise men among the Greeks flourished after the age of Moses, will, a little after, be shown.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:11
verses.text: But the style of philosophy among them, as Hebraic and enigmatical, is now to be considered.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:12
verses.text: They adopted brevity, as suited for exhortation, and most useful.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:13
verses.text: Even Plato says, that of old this mode was purposely in vogue among all the Greeks, especially the Lacedaemonians and Cretans, who enjoyed the best laws.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:14
verses.text: The expression, "Know thyself," some supposed to be Chilon's.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:15
verses.text: But Chamaeleon, in his book About the Gods, ascribes it to Thales; Aristotle to the Pythian.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:16
verses.text: It may be an injunction to the pursuit of knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:17
verses.text: For it is not possible to know the parts without the essence of the whole; and one must study the genesis of the universe, that thereby we may be able to learn the nature of man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:18
verses.text: Again, to Chilon the Lacedaemonian they attribute, "Let nothing be too much".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:19
verses.text: Strato, in his book Of Inventions, ascribes the apophthegm to Stratodemus of Tegea.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:20
verses.text: Didymus assigns it to Solon; as also to Cleobulus the saying, "A middle course is best".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:21
verses.text: And the expression, "Come under a pledge, and mischief is at hand," Cleomenes says, in his book Concerning Hesiod, was uttered before by Homer in the lines:—  "Wretched pledges, for the wretched, to be pledged".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:22
verses.text: The Aristotelians judge it to be Chilon's; but Didymus says the advice was that of Thales.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:23
verses.text: Then, next in order, the saying, "All men are bad," or, "The most of men are bad" (for the same apophthegm is expressed in two ways), Sotades the Byzantian says that it was Bias's.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:24
verses.text: And the aphorism, "Practice conquers everything," they will have it to be Periander's; and likewise the advice, "Know the opportunity," to have been a saying of Pittacus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:25
verses.text: Solon made laws for the Athenians, Pittacus for the Mitylenians.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:26
verses.text: And at a late date, Pythagoras, the pupil of Pherecydes, first called himself a philosopher.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:27
verses.text: Accordingly, after the fore-mentioned three men, there were three schools of philosophy, named after the places where they lived: the Italic from Pythagoras, the Ionic from Thales, the Eleatic from Xenophanes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:28
verses.text: Pythagoras was a Samian, the son of Mnesarchus, as Hippobotus says: according to Aristoxenus, in his life of Pythagoras and Aristarchus and Theopompus, he was a Tuscan; and according to Neanthes, a Syrian or a Tyrian.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:29
verses.text: So that Pythagoras was, according to the most, of barbarian extraction.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:30
verses.text: Thales, too, as Leander and Herodotus relate, was a Phoenician; as some suppose, a Milesian.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:31
verses.text: He alone seems to have met the prophets of the Egyptians.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:32
verses.text: But no one is described as his teacher, nor is any one mentioned as the teacher of Pherecydes of Syros, who had Pythagoras as his pupil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:33
verses.text: But the Italic philosophy, that of Pythagoras, grew old in Metapontum in Italy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:34
verses.text: Anaximander of Miletus, the son of Praxiades, succeeded Thales; and was himself succeeded by Anaximenes of Miletus, the son of Eurustratus; after whom came Anaxagoras of Clazomenae, the son of Hegesibulus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:35
verses.text: He transferred his school from Ionia to Athens.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:36
verses.text: He was succeeded by Archelaus, whose pupil Socrates was.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:37
verses.text: "From these turned aside, the stone-mason; Talker about laws; the enchanter of the Greeks,"  says Timon in his Satirical Poems, on account of his quitting physics for ethics.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:38
verses.text: Antisthenes, after being a pupil of Socrates, introduced the Cynic philosophy; and Plato withdrew to the Academy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:39
verses.text: Aristotle, after studying philosophy under Plato, withdrew to the Lyceum, and founded the Peripatetic sect.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:40
verses.text: He was succeeded by Theophrastus, who was succeeded by Strato, and he by Lycon, then Critolaus, and then Diodorus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:41
verses.text: Speusippus was the successor of Plato; his successor was Xenocrates; and the successor of the latter, Polemo.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:42
verses.text: And the disciples of Polemo were Crates and Crantor, in whom the old Academy founded by Plato ceased.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:43
verses.text: Arcesilaus was the associate of Crantor; from whom, down to Hegesilaus, the Middle Academy flourished.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:44
verses.text: Then Carneades succeeded Hegesilaus, and others came in succession.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:45
verses.text: The disciple of Crates was Zeno of Citium, the founder of the Stoic sect.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:46
verses.text: He was succeeded by Cleanthes; and the latter by Chrysippus, and others after him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:47
verses.text: Xenophanes of Colophon was the founder of the Eleatic school, who, Timaeus says, lived in the time of Hiero, lord of Sicily, and Epicharmus the poet; and Apollodorus says that he was born in the fortieth Olympiad, and reached to the times of Darius and Cyrus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:48
verses.text: Parmenides, accordingly, was the disciple of Xenophanes, and Zeno of him; then came Leucippus,  and then Democritus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:49
verses.text: Disciples of Democritus were Protagoras of Abdera, and Metrodorus of Chios, whose pupil was Diogenes of Smyrna; and his again Anaxarchus, and his Pyrrho, and his Nausiphanes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:50
verses.text: Some say that Epicurus was a scholar of his.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:51
verses.text: Such, in an epitome, is the succession of the philosophers among the Greeks.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:52
verses.text: The periods of the originators of their philosophy are now to be specified successively, in order that, by comparison, we may show that the Hebrew philosophy was older by many generations.
