verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:53
verses.text: It has been said of Xenophanes that he was the founder of the Eleatic philosophy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:54
verses.text: And Eudemus, in the Astrological Histories, says that Thales foretold the eclipse of the sun, which took place at the time that the Medians and the Lydians fought, in the reign of Cyaxares the father of Astyages over the Medes, and of Alyattus the son of Croesus over the Lydians.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:55
verses.text: Herodotus in his first book agrees with him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:56
verses.text: The date is about the fiftieth Olympiad.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:57
verses.text: Pythagoras is ascertained to have lived in the days of Polycrates the tyrant, about the sixty-second Olympiad.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:58
verses.text: Mnesiphilus is described as a follower of Solon, and was a contemporary of Themistocles.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:59
verses.text: Solon therefore flourished about the forty-sixth Olympiad.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:60
verses.text: For Heraclitus, the son of Bauso, persuaded Melancomas the tyrant to abdicate his sovereignty.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 12:61
verses.text: He despised the invitation of king Darius to visit the Persians.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:1
verses.text: Chapter 15—The Greek Philosophy in Great Part Derived from the Barbarians.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:2
verses.text: These are the times of the oldest wise men and philosophers among the Greeks.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:3
verses.text: And that the most of them were barbarians by extraction, and were trained among barbarians, what need is there to say? Pythagoras is shown to have been either a Tuscan or a Tyrian.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:4
verses.text: And Antisthenes was a Phrygian.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:5
verses.text: And Orpheus was an Odrysian or a Thracian.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:6
verses.text: The most, too, show Homer to have been an Egyptian.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:7
verses.text: Thales was a Phoenician by birth, and was said to have consorted with the prophets of the Egyptians; as also Pythagoras did with the same persons, by whom he was circumcised, that he might enter the adytum and learn from the Egyptians the mystic philosophy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:8
verses.text: He held converse with the chief of the Chaldeans and the Magi; and he gave a hint of the church, now so called, in the common hall which he maintained.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:9
verses.text: And Plato does not deny that he procured all that is most excellent in philosophy from the barbarians; and he admits that he came into Egypt.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:10
verses.text: Whence, writing in the Phoedo that the philosopher can receive aid from all sides, he said: "Great indeed is Greece, O Cebes, in which everywhere there are good men, and many are the races of the barbarians".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:11
verses.text: Thus Plato thinks that some of the barbarians, too, are philosophers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:12
verses.text: But Epicurus, on the other hand, supposes that only Greeks can philosophise.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:13
verses.text: And in the Symposium, Plato, landing the barbarians as practising philosophy with conspicuous excellence, truly says: "And in many other instances both among Greeks and barbarians, whose temples reared for such sons are already numerous".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:14
verses.text: And it is clear that the barbarians signally honoured their lawgivers and teachers, designating them gods.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:15
verses.text: For, according to Plato, "they think that good souls, on quitting the super-celestial region, submit to come to this Tartarus; and assuming a body, share in all the ills which are involved in birth, from their solicitude for the race of men;" and these make laws and publish philosophy, "than which no greater boon ever came from the gods to the race of men, or will come".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:16
verses.text: And as appears to me, it was in consequence of perceiving the great benefit which is conferred through wise men, that the men themselves were honoured and philosophy cultivated publicly by all the Brahmins, and the Odrysi, and the Getae.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:17
verses.text: And such were strictly deified by the race of the Egyptians, by the Chaldeans and the Arabians, called the Happy, and those that inhabited Palestine, by not the least portion of the Persian race, and by innumerable other races besides these.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:18
verses.text: And it is well known that Plato is found perpetually celebrating the barbarians, remembering that both himself and Pythagoras learned the most and the noblest of their dogmas among the barbarians.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:19
verses.text: Wherefore he also called the races of the barbarians, "races of barbarian philosophers," recognising, in the Phoedrus, the Egyptian king, and shows him to us wiser than Theut, whom he knew to be Hermes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:20
verses.text: But in the Charmides, it is manifest that he knew certain Thracians who were said to make the soul immortal.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:21
verses.text: And Pythagoras is reported to have been a disciple of Sonches the Egyptian arch-prophet; and Plato, of Sechnuphis of Heliopolis; and Eudoxus, of Cnidius of Konuphis, who was also an Egyptian.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:22
verses.text: And in his book, On the Soul, Plato again manifestly recognises prophecy, when he introduces a prophet announcing  the word of Lachesis, uttering predictions to the souls whose destiny is becoming fixed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:23
verses.text: And in the Timaeus he introduces Solon, the very wise, learning from the barbarian.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:24
verses.text: The substance of the declaration is to the following effect: "O Solon, Solon, you Greeks are always children.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:25
verses.text: And no Greek is an old man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:26
verses.text: For you have no learning that is hoary with age".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:27
verses.text: Democritus appropriated the Babylonian ethic discourses, for he is said to have combined with his own compositions a translation of the column of Acicarus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:28
verses.text: And you may find the distinction notified by him when he writes, "Thus says Democritus".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:29
verses.text: About himself, too, where, pluming himself on his erudition, he says, "I have roamed over the most ground of any man of my time, investigating the most remote parts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:30
verses.text: I have seen the most skies and lands, and I have heard of learned men in very great numbers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:31
verses.text: And in composition no one has surpassed me; in demonstration, not even those among the Egyptians who are called Arpenodaptae, with all of whom I lived in exile up to eighty years".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:32
verses.text: For he went to Babylon, and Persis, and Egypt, to learn from the Magi and the priests.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:33
verses.text: Zoroaster the Magus, Pythagoras showed to be a Persian.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:34
verses.text: Of the secret books of this man, those who follow the heresy of Prodicus boast to be in possession.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:35
verses.text: Alexander, in his book On the Pythagorean Symbols, relates that Pythagoras was a pupil of Nazaratus the Assyrian (some think that he is Ezekiel; but he is not, as will afterwards be shown), and will have it that, in addition to these, Pythagoras was a hearer of the Galatae and the Brahmins.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:36
verses.text: Clearchus the Peripatetic says that he knew a Jew who associated with Aristotle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:37
verses.text: Heraclitus says that, not humanly, but rather by God's aid, the Sibyl spoke.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:38
verses.text: They say, accordingly, that at Delphi a stone was shown beside the oracle, on which, it is said, sat the first Sibyl, who came from Helicon, and had been reared by the Muses.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:39
verses.text: But some say that she came from Milea, being the daughter of Lamia of Sidon.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:40
verses.text: And Serapion, in his epic verses, says that the Sibyl, even when dead, ceased not from divination.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:41
verses.text: And he writes that, what proceeded from her into the air after her death, was what gave oracular utterances in voices and omens; and on her body being changed into earth, and the grass as natural growing out of it, whatever beasts happening to be in that place fed on it exhibited to men an accurate knowledge of futurity by their entrails.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:42
verses.text: He thinks also, that the face seen in the moon is her soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:43
verses.text: So much for the Sibyl.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:44
verses.text: Numa the king of the Romans was a Pythagorean, and aided by the precepts of Moses, prohibited from making an image of God in human form, and of the shape of a living creature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:45
verses.text: Accordingly, during the first hundred and seventy years, though building temples, they made no cast or graven image.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:46
verses.text: For Numa secretly showed them that the Best of Beings could not be apprehended except by the mind alone.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:47
verses.text: Thus philosophy, a thing of the highest utility, flourished in antiquity among the barbarians, shedding its light over the nations.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:48
verses.text: And afterwards it came to Greece.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:49
verses.text: First in its ranks were the prophets of the Egyptians; and the Chaldeans among the Assyrians; and the Druids among the Gauls; and the Samanaeans among the Bactrians; and the philosophers of the Celts; and the Magi of the Persians, who foretold the Saviour's birth, and came into the land of Judaea guided by a star.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:50
verses.text: The Indian gymnosophists are also in the number, and the other barbarian philosophers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:51
verses.text: And of these there are two classes, some of them called Sarmanae, and others Brahmins.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:52
verses.text: And those of the Sarmanae who are called Hylobii neither inhabit cities, nor have roofs over them, but are clothed in the bark of trees, feed on nuts, and drink water in their hands.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:53
verses.text: Like those called Encratites in the present day, they know not marriage nor begetting of children.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:54
verses.text: Some, too, of the Indians obey the precepts of Buddha; whom, on account of his extraordinary sanctity, they have raised to divine honours.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:55
verses.text: Anacharsis was a Scythian, and is recorded to have excelled many philosophers among the Greeks.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:56
verses.text: And the Hyperboreans, Hellanicus relates, dwelt beyond the Riphaean mountains, and inculcated justice, not eating flesh, but using nuts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:57
verses.text: Those who are sixty years old they take without the gates, and do away with.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:58
verses.text: There are also among the Germans those called sacred women, who, by inspecting the whirlpools of rivers and the eddies, and observing the noises of streams, presage and predict future events.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:59
verses.text: These did not allow the men to fight against Caesar till the new moon shone.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:60
verses.text: Of all these, by far the oldest is the Jewish race; and that their philosophy committed to writing has the precedence of philosophy among the Greeks, the Pythagorean Philo shows at large; and, besides him, Aristobulus the Peripatetic, and several others, not to waste time, in  going over them by name.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:61
verses.text: Very clearly the author Megasthenes, the contemporary of Seleucus Nicanor, writes as follows in the third of his books, On Indian Affairs: "All that was said about nature by the ancients is said also by those who philosophise beyond Greece: some things by the Brahmins among the Indians, and others by those called Jews in Syria".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:62
verses.text: Some more fabulously say that certain of those called the Idaean Dactyli were the first wise men; to whom are attributed the invention of what are called the "Ephesian letters," and of numbers in music.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:63
verses.text: For which reason dactyls in music received their name.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:64
verses.text: And the Idaean Dactyli were Phrygians and barbarians.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:65
verses.text: Herodotus relates that Hercules, having grown a sage and a student of physics, received from the barbarian Atlas, the Phrygian, the columns of the universe; the fable meaning that he received by instruction the knowledge of the heavenly bodies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:66
verses.text: And Hermippus of Berytus calls Charon the Centaur wise; about whom, he that wrote The Battle of the Titans says, "that he first led the race of mortals to righteousness, by teaching them the solemnity of the oath, and propitiatory sacrifices and the figures of Olympus".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:67
verses.text: By him Achilles, who fought at Troy, was taught.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:68
verses.text: And Hippo, the daughter of the Centaur, who dwelt with aeolus, taught him her father's science, the knowledge of physics.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:69
verses.text: Euripides also testifies of Hippo as follows:—  "Who first, by oracles, presaged, And by the rising stars, events divine".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:70
verses.text: By this aeolus, Ulysses was received as a guest after the taking of Troy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 13:71
verses.text: Mark the epochs by comparison with the age of Moses, and with the high antiquity of the philosophy promulgated by him.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:1
verses.text: Chapter 16—That the Inventors of Other Arts Were Mostly Barbarians.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:2
verses.text: And barbarians were inventors not only of philosophy, but almost of every art.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:3
verses.text: The Egyptians were the first to introduce astrology among men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:4
verses.text: Similarly also the Chaldeans.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:5
verses.text: The Egyptians first showed how to burn lamps, and divided the year into twelve months, prohibited intercourse with women in the temples, and enacted that no one should enter the temples from a woman without bathing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:6
verses.text: Again, they were the inventors of geometry.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:7
verses.text: There are some who say that the Carians invented prognostication by the stars.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:8
verses.text: The Phrygians were the first who attended to the flight of birds.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:9
verses.text: And the Tuscans, neighbours of Italy, were adepts at the art of the Haruspex.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:10
verses.text: The Isaurians and the Arabians invented augury, as the Telmesians divination by dreams.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:11
verses.text: The Etruscans invented the trumpet, and the Phrygians the flute.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:12
verses.text: For Olympus and Marsyas were Phrygians.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:13
verses.text: And Cadmus, the inventor of letters among the Greeks, as Euphorus says, was a Phoenician; whence also Herodotus writes that they were called Phoenician letters.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:14
verses.text: And they say that the Phoenicians and the Syrians first invented letters; and that Apis, an aboriginal inhabitant of Egypt, invented the healing art before Io came into Egypt.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:15
verses.text: But afterwards they say that Asclepius improved the art.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:16
verses.text: Atlas the Libyan was the first who built a ship and navigated the sea.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:17
verses.text: Kelmis and Damnaneus, Idaean Dactyli, first discovered iron in Cyprus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:18
verses.text: Another Idaean discovered the tempering of brass; according to Hesiod, a Scythian.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:19
verses.text: The Thracians first invented what is called a scimitar (ἅρπη),—it is a curved sword,—and were the first to use shields on horseback.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:20
verses.text: Similarly also the Illyrians invented the shield (πέλτη).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:21
verses.text: Besides, they say that the Tuscans invented the art of moulding clay; and that Itanus (he was a Samnite) first fashioned the oblong shield (θυρέος).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:22
verses.text: Cadmus the Phoenician invented stonecutting, and discovered the gold mines on the Pangaean mountain.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:23
verses.text: Further, another nation, the Cappadocians, first invented the instrument called the nabla, and the Assyrians in the same way the dichord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:24
verses.text: The Carthaginians were the first that constructed a trireme; and it was built by Bosporus, an aboriginal.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:25
verses.text: Medea, the daughter of aeetas, a Colchian, first invented the dyeing of hair.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:26
verses.text: Besides, the Noropes (they are a Paeonian race, and are now called the Norici) worked copper, and were the first that purified iron.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:27
verses.text: Amycus the king of the Bebryci was the first inventor of boxing-gloves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:28
verses.text: In music, Olympus the Mysian practiced the Lydian harmony; and the people called Troglodytes invented the sambuca, a musical instrument.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:29
verses.text: It is said that the crooked pipe was invented by Satyrus the Phrygian; likewise also diatonic harmony by Hyagnis, a Phrygian too; and notes by Olympus, a Phrygian; as also the Phrygian harmony, and the half-Phrygian and the half-Lydian, by Marsyas, who belonged to the same region as those mentioned above.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:30
verses.text: And the Doric was invented by Thamyris the Thracian.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:31
verses.text: We have heard that the Persians were the first who fashioned the chariot, and bed, and footstool; and the Sidonians the first to construct a trireme.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:32
verses.text: The Sicilians, close to Italy, were the first inventors of the phorminx, which is not much inferior to the lyre.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:33
verses.text: And they invented castanets.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:34
verses.text: In the  time of Semiramis queen of the Assyrians, they relate that linen garments were invented.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:35
verses.text: And Hellanicus says that Atossa queen of the Persians was the first who composed a letter.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:36
verses.text: These things are reported by Scamo of Mitylene, Theophrastus of Ephesus, Cydippus of Mantinea, also Antiphanes, Aristodemus, and Aristotle; and besides these, Philostephanus, and also Strato the Peripatetic, in his books Concerning Inventions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:37
verses.text: I have added a few details from them, in order to confirm the inventive and practically useful genius of the barbarians, by whom the Greeks profited in their studies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:38
verses.text: And if any one objects to the barbarous language, Anacharsis says, "All the Greeks speak Scythian to me".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:39
verses.text: It was he who was held in admiration by the Greeks, who said, "My covering is a cloak; my supper, milk and cheese".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:40
verses.text: You see that the barbarian philosophy professes deeds, not words.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:41
verses.text: The apostle thus speaks: "So likewise ye, except ye utter by the tongue a word easy to be understood, how shall ye know what is spoken? for ye shall speak into the air.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:42
verses.text: There are, it may be, so many kind of voices in the world, and none of them is without signification.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:43
verses.text: Therefore if I know not the meaning of the voice, I shall be unto him that speaketh a barbarian, and he that speaketh shall be a barbarian unto me".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:44
verses.text: And, "Let him that speaketh in an unknown tongue pray that he may interpret".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:45
verses.text: Nay more, it was late before the teaching and writing of discourses reached Greece.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:46
verses.text: Alcmaeon, the son of Perithus, of Crotona, first composed a treatise on nature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:47
verses.text: And it is related that Anaxagoras of Clazomenae, the son of Hegesibulus, first published a book in writing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:48
verses.text: The first to adapt music to poetical compositions was Terpander of Antissa; and he set the laws of the Lacedaemonians to music.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:49
verses.text: Lasus of Hermione invented the dithyramb; Stesichorus of Himera, the hymn; Alcman the Spartan, the choral song; Anacreon of Teos, love songs; Pindar the Theban, the dance accompanied with song.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:50
verses.text: Timotheus of Miletus was the first to execute those musical compositions called νόμοι on the lyre, with dancing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:51
verses.text: Moreover, the iambus was invented by Archilochus of Paros, and the choliambus by Hipponax of Ephesus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:52
verses.text: Tragedy owed its origin to Thespis the Athenian, and comedy to Susarion of Icaria.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:53
verses.text: Their dates are handed down by the grammarians.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:54
verses.text: But it were tedious to specify them accurately: presently, however, Dionysus, on whose account the Dionysian spectacles are celebrated, will be shown to be later than Moses.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:55
verses.text: They say that Antiphon of Rhamnusium, the son of Sophilus, first invented scholastic discourses and rhetorical figures, and was the first who pled causes for a fee, and wrote a forensic speech for delivery, as Diodorus says.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:56
verses.text: And Apollodorus of Cuma first assumed the name of critic, and was called a grammarian.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:57
verses.text: Some say it was Eratosthenes of Cyrene who was first so called, since he published two books which he entitled Grammatica.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:58
verses.text: The first who was called a grammarian, as we now use the term, was Praxiphanes, the son of Disnysophenes of Mitylene.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:59
verses.text: Zeleucus the Locrian was reported to have been the first to have framed laws (in writing).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:60
verses.text: Others say that it was Menos the son of Zeus, in the time of Lynceus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:61
verses.text: He comes after Danaus, in the eleventh generation from Inachus and Moses; as we shall show a little further on.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:62
verses.text: And Lycurgus, who lived many years after the taking of Troy, legislated for the Lacedaemonians a hundred and fifty years before the Olympiads.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:63
verses.text: We have spoken before of the age of Solon.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:64
verses.text: Draco (he was a legislator too) is discovered to have lived about the three hundred and ninth Olympiad.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:65
verses.text: Antilochus, again, who wrote of the learned men from the age of Pythagoras to the death of Epicurus, which took place in the tenth day of the month Gamelion, makes up altogether three hundred and twelve years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:66
verses.text: Moreover, some say that Phanothea, the wife of Icarius, invented the heroic hexameter; others Themis, one of the Titanides.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:67
verses.text: Didymus, however, in his work On the Pythagorean Philosophy, relates that Theano of Crotona was the first woman who cultivated philosophy and composed poems.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:68
verses.text: The Hellenic philosophy then, according to some, apprehended the truth accidentally, dimly, partially; as others will have it, was set a-going by the devil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:69
verses.text: Several suppose that certain powers, descending from heaven, inspired the whole of philosophy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 14:70
verses.text: But if the Hellenic philosophy comprehends not the whole extent of the truth, and besides is destitute of strength to perform the commandments of the Lord, yet it prepares the way for the truly royal teaching; training in some way or other, and moulding the character, and fitting him who believes in Providence for the reception of the truth.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:1
verses.text: Chapter 17—On the Saying of the Saviour, "All that Came Before Me Were Thieves and Robbers".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:2
verses.text: But, say they, it is written, "All who were before the Lord's advent are thieves and robbers".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:3
verses.text: All, then, who are in the Word (for it is these that were previous to the incarnation of the Word) are understood generally.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:4
verses.text: But the  prophets, being sent and inspired by the Lord, were not thieves, but servants.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:5
verses.text: The Scripture accordingly says, "Wisdom sent her servants, inviting with loud proclamation to a goblet of wine".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:6
verses.text: But philosophy, it is said, was not sent by the Lord, but came stolen, or given by a thief.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:7
verses.text: It was then some power or angel that had learned something of the truth, but abode not in it, that inspired and taught these things, not without the Lord's knowledge, who knew before the constitution of each essence the issues of futurity, but without His prohibition.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:8
verses.text: For the theft which reached men then, had some advantage; not that he who perpetrated the theft had utility in his eye, but Providence directed the issue of the audacious deed to utility.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:9
verses.text: I know that many are perpetually assailing us with the allegation, that not to prevent a thing happening, is to be the cause of it happening.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:10
verses.text: For they say, that the man who does not take precaution against a theft, or does not prevent it, is the cause of it: as he is the cause of the conflagration who has not quenched it at the beginning; and the master of the vessel who does not reef the sail, is the cause of the shipwreck.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:11
verses.text: Certainly those who are the causes of such events are punished by the law.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:12
verses.text: For to him who had power to prevent, attaches the blame of what happens.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:13
verses.text: We say to them, that causation is seen in doing, working, acting; but the not preventing is in this respect inoperative.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:14
verses.text: Further, causation attaches to activity; as in the case of the shipbuilder in relation to the origin of the vessel, and the builder in relation to the construction of the house.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:15
verses.text: But that which does not prevent is separated from what takes place.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:16
verses.text: Wherefore the effect will be accomplished; because that which could have prevented neither acts nor prevents.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:17
verses.text: For what activity does that which prevents not exert? Now their assertion is reduced to absurdity, if they shall say that the cause of the wound is not the dart, but the shield, which did not prevent the dart from passing through; and if they blame not the thief, but the man who did not prevent the theft.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:18
verses.text: Let them then say, that it was not Hector that burned the ships of the Greeks, but Achilles; because, having the power to prevent Hector, he did not prevent him; but out of anger (and it depended on himself to be angry or not) did not keep back the fire, and was a concurring cause.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:19
verses.text: Now the devil, being possessed of free-will, was able both to repent and to steal; and it was he who was the author of the theft, not the Lord, who did not prevent him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:20
verses.text: But neither was the gift hurtful, so as to require that prevention should intervene.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:21
verses.text: But if strict accuracy must be employed in dealing with them, let them know, that that which does not prevent what we assert to have taken place in the theft, is not a cause at all; but that what prevents is involved in the accusation of being a cause.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:22
verses.text: For he that protects with a shield is the cause of him whom he protects not being wounded; preventing him, as he does, from being wounded.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:23
verses.text: For the demon of Socrates was a cause, not by not preventing, but by exhorting, even if (strictly speaking) he did not exhort.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:24
verses.text: And neither praises nor censures, neither rewards nor punishments, are right, when the soul has not the power of inclination and disinclination, but evil is involuntary.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:25
verses.text: Whence he who prevents is a cause; while he who prevents not judges justly the soul's choice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:26
verses.text: So in no respect is God the author of evil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:27
verses.text: But since free choice and inclination originate sins, and a mistaken judgment sometimes prevails, from which, since it is ignorance and stupidity, we do not take pains to recede, punishments are rightly inflicted.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:28
verses.text: For to take fever is involuntary; but when one takes fever through his own fault, from excess, we blame him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:29
verses.text: Inasmuch, then, as evil is involuntary,—for no one prefers evil as evil; but induced by the pleasure that is in it, and imagining it good, considers it desirable;—such being the case, to free ourselves from ignorance, and from evil and voluptuous choice, and above all, to withhold our assent from those delusive phantasies, depends on ourselves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:30
verses.text: The devil is called "thief and robber;" having mixed false prophets with the prophets, as tares with the wheat.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:31
verses.text: "All, then, that came before the Lord, were thieves and robbers;" not absolutely all men, but all the false prophets, and all who were not properly sent by Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:32
verses.text: For the false prophets possessed the prophetic name dishonestly, being prophets, but prophets of the liar.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:33
verses.text: For the Lord says, "Ye are of your father the devil; and the lusts of your father ye will do.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:34
verses.text: He was a murderer from the beginning, and abode not in the truth, because there is no truth in him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:35
verses.text: When he speaketh a lie, he speaketh of his own; for he is a liar, and the father of it".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:36
verses.text: But among the lies, the false prophets also told some true things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:37
verses.text: And in reality they prophesied "in an ecstasy," as the servants of the apostate.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:38
verses.text: And the Shepherd, the angel of repentance, says to Hermas, of the false prophet: "For he speaks some truths.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:39
verses.text: For the devil fills him with his own spirit, if perchance he may be able to cast down any one from what is right".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:40
verses.text: All things, therefore, are dispensed from heaven for good, "that by the Church may be made known the manifold wisdom of God, according  to the eternal foreknowledge, which He purposed in Christ".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:41
verses.text: Nothing withstands God: nothing opposes Him: seeing He is Lord and omnipotent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:42
verses.text: Further, the counsels and activities of those who have rebelled, being partial, proceed from a bad disposition, as bodily diseases from a bad constitution, but are guided by universal Providence to a salutary issue, even though the cause be productive of disease.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:43
verses.text: It is accordingly the greatest achievement of divine Providence, not to allow the evil, which has sprung from voluntary apostasy, to remain useless, and for no good, and not to become in all respects injurious.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:44
verses.text: For it is the work of the divine wisdom, and excellence, and power, not alone to do good (for this is, so to speak, the nature of God, as it is of fire to warm and of light to illumine), but especially to ensure that what happens through the evils hatched by any, may come to a good and useful issue, and to use to advantage those things which appear to be evils, as also the testimony which accrues from temptation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:45
verses.text: There is then in philosophy, though stolen as the fire by Prometheus, a slender spark, capable of being fanned into flame, a trace of wisdom and an impulse from God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:46
verses.text: Well, be it so that "the thieves and robbers" are the philosophers among the Greeks, who from the Hebrew prophets before the coming of the Lord received fragments of the truth, not with full knowledge, and claimed these as their own teachings, disguising some points, treating others sophistically by their ingenuity, and discovering other things, for perchance they had "the spirit of perception".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:47
verses.text: Aristotle, too, assented to Scripture, and declared sophistry to have stolen wisdom, as we intimated before.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:48
verses.text: And the apostle says, "Which things we speak, not in the words which man's wisdom teacheth, but which the Holy Ghost teacheth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:49
verses.text: For of the prophets it is said, "We have all received of His fulness," that is, of Christ's.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:50
verses.text: So that the prophets are not thieves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:51
verses.text: "And my doctrine is not Mine," saith the Lord, "but the Father's which sent me".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:52
verses.text: And of those who steal He says: "But he that speaketh of himself, seeketh his own glory".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:53
verses.text: Such are the Greeks, "lovers of their own selves, and boasters".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 15:54
verses.text: Scripture, when it speaks of these as wise, does not brand those who are really wise, but those who are wise in appearance.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 16

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 16:1
verses.text: Chapter 18—He Illustrates the Apostle's Saying, "I Will Destroy the Wisdom of the Wise".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 16:2
verses.text: And of such it is said, "I will destroy the wisdom of the wise: I will bring to nothing the understanding of the prudent".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 16:3
verses.text: The apostle accordingly adds, "Where is the wise? Where is the scribe? Where is the disputer of this world?" setting in contradistinction to the scribes, the disputers of this world, the philosophers of the Gentiles.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 16:4
verses.text: "Hath not God made foolish the wisdom of the world?" which is equivalent to, showed it to be foolish, and not true, as they thought.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 16:5
verses.text: And if you ask the cause of their seeming wisdom, he will say, "because of the blindness of their heart;" since "in the wisdom of God," that is, as proclaimed by the prophets, "the world knew not," in the wisdom "which spake by the prophets," "Him," that is, God,—"it pleased God by the foolishness of preaching"—what seemed to the Greeks foolishness—"to save them that believe.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 16:6
verses.text: For the Jews require signs," in order to faith; "and the Greeks seek after wisdom," plainly those reasonings styled "irresistible," and those others, namely, syllogisms.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 16:7
verses.text: "But we preach Jesus Christ crucified; to the Jews a stumbling-block," because, though knowing prophecy, they did not believe the event: "to the Greeks, foolishness;" for those who in their own estimation are wise, consider it fabulous that the Son of God should speak by man and that God should have a Son, and especially that that Son should have suffered.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 16:8
verses.text: Whence their preconceived idea inclines them to disbelieve.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 16:9
verses.text: For the advent of the Saviour did not make people foolish, and hard of heart, and unbelieving, but made them understanding, amenable to persuasion, and believing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 16:10
verses.text: But those that would not believe, by separating themselves from the voluntary adherence of those who obeyed, were proved to be without understanding, unbelievers and fools.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 16:11
verses.text: "But to them who are called, both Jews and Greeks, Christ is the power of God, and the wisdom of God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 16:12
verses.text: Should we not understand (as is better) the words rendered, "Hath not God made foolish the wisdom of the world?" negatively: "God hath not made foolish the wisdom of the world?"—so that the cause of their hardness of heart may not appear to have proceeded from God, "making foolish the wisdom of the world".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 16:13
verses.text: For on all accounts, being wise, they incur greater blame in not believing the proclamation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 16:14
verses.text: For the preference and choice of truth is voluntary.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 16:15
verses.text: But that declaration, "I will destroy the wisdom of the wise," declares Him to have sent forth light, by bringing forth in opposition the despised and contemned barbarian philosophy; as the lamp, when shone upon by the sun, is said to be extinguished, on account of its not then exerting  the same power.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 16:16
verses.text: All having been therefore called, those who are willing to obey have been named "called".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 16:17
verses.text: For there is no unrighteousness with God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 16:18
verses.text: Those of either race who have believed, are "a peculiar people".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 16:19
verses.text: And in the Acts of the Apostles you will find this, word for word, "Those then who received his word were baptized;" but those who would not obey kept themselves aloof.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 16:20
verses.text: To these prophecy says, "If ye be willing and hear me, ye shall eat the good things of the land;" proving that choice or refusal depends on ourselves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 16:21
verses.text: The apostle designates the doctrine which is according to the Lord, "the wisdom of God," in order to show that the true philosophy has been communicated by the Son.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 16:22
verses.text: Further, he, who has a show of wisdom, has certain exhortations enjoined on him by the apostle: "That ye put on the new man, which after God is renewed in righteousness and true holiness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 16:23
verses.text: Wherefore, putting away lying, speak every man truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 16:24
verses.text: Neither give place to the devil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 16:25
verses.text: Let him that stole, steal no more; but rather let him labour, working that which is good" (and to work is to labour in seeking the truth; for it is accompanied with rational well-doing), "that ye may have to give to him that has need," both of worldly wealth and of divine wisdom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 16:26
verses.text: For he wishes both that the word be taught, and that the money be put into the bank, accurately tested, to accumulate interest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 16:27
verses.text: Whence he adds, "Let no corrupt communication proceed out of your mouth,"—that is "corrupt communication" which proceeds out of conceit,—"but that which is good for the use of edifying, that it may minister grace to the hearers".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 16:28
verses.text: And the word of the good God must needs be good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 16:29
verses.text: And how is it possible that he who saves shall not be good?.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:1
verses.text: Chapter 19—That the Philosophers Have Attained to Some Portion of Truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:2
verses.text: Since, then, the Greeks are testified to have laid down some true opinions, we may from this point take a glance at the testimonies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:3
verses.text: Paul, in the Acts of the Apostles, is recorded to have said to the Areopagites, "I perceive that ye are more than ordinarily religious.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:4
verses.text: For as I passed by, and beheld your devotions, I found an altar with the inscription, To The Unknown God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:5
verses.text: Whom therefore ye ignorantly worship, Him declare I unto you.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:6
verses.text: God, that made the world and all things therein, seeing that He is Lord of heaven and earth, dwelleth not in temples made with hands; neither is worshipped with men's hands, as though He needed anything, seeing He giveth to all life, and breath, and all things; and hath made of one blood all nations of men to dwell on all the face of the earth, and hath determined the times before appointed, and the bounds of their habitation; that they should seek God, if haply they might feel after Him, and find Him; though He be not far from every one of us: for in Him we live, and move, and have our being; as certain also of your own poets have said, For we also are His offspring".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:7
verses.text: Whence it is evident that the apostle, by availing himself of poetical examples from the Phenomena of Aratus, approves of what had been well spoken by the Greeks; and intimates that, by the unknown God, God the Creator was in a roundabout way worshipped by the Greeks; but that it was necessary by positive knowledge to apprehend and learn Him by the Son.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:8
verses.text: "Wherefore, then, I send thee to the Gentiles," it is said, "to open their eyes, and to turn them from darkness to light, and from the power of Satan unto God; that they may receive forgiveness of sins, and inheritance among them that are sanctified by faith which is in Me".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:9
verses.text: Such, then, are the eyes of the blind which are opened.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:10
verses.text: The knowledge of the Father by the Son is the comprehension of the "Greek circumlocution;" and to turn from the power of Satan is to change from sin, through which bondage was produced.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:11
verses.text: We do not, indeed, receive absolutely all philosophy, but that of which Socrates speaks in Plato.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:12
verses.text: "For there are (as they say) in the mysteries many bearers of the thyrsus, but few bacchanals;" meaning, "that many are called, but few chosen".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:13
verses.text: He accordingly plainly adds: "These, in my opinion, are none else than those who have philosophized right; to belong to whose number, I myself have left nothing undone in life, as far as I could, but have endeavoured in every way.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:14
verses.text: Whether we have endeavoured rightly and achieved aught, we shall know when we have gone there, if God will, a little afterwards".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:15
verses.text: Does he not then seem to declare from the Hebrew Scriptures the righteous man's hope, through faith, after death? And in Demodocus (if that is really the work of Plato): "And do not imagine that I call it philosophizing to spend life pottering about the arts, or learning many  things, but something different; since I, at least, would consider this a disgrace".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:16
verses.text: For he knew, I reckon, "that the knowledge of many things does not educate the mind," according to Heraclitus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:17
verses.text: And in the fifth book of the Republic, he says, "'Shall we then call all these, and the others which study such things, and those who apply themselves to the meaner arts, philosophers?' 'By no means,' I said, 'but like philosophers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:18
verses.text: ' 'And whom,' said he, 'do you call true?' 'Those,' said I, 'who delight in the contemplation of truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:19
verses.text: For philosophy is not in geometry, with its postulates and hypotheses; nor in music, which is conjectural; nor in astronomy, crammed full of physical, fluid, and probable causes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:20
verses.text: But the knowledge of the good and truth itself are requisite,—what is good being one thing, and the ways to the good another.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:21
verses.text: '" So that he does not allow that the curriculum of training suffices for the good, but co-operates in rousing and training the soul to intellectual objects.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:22
verses.text: Whether, then, they say that the Greeks gave forth some utterances of the true philosophy by accident, it is the accident of a divine administration (for no one will, for the sake of the present argument with us, deify chance); or by good fortune, good fortune is not unforeseen.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:23
verses.text: Or were one, on the other hand, to say that the Greeks possessed a natural conception of these things, we know the one Creator of nature; just as we also call righteousness natural; or that they had a common intellect, let us reflect who is its father, and what righteousness is in the mental economy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:24
verses.text: For were one to name "prediction," and assign as its cause "combined utterance," he specifies forms of prophecy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:25
verses.text: Further, others will have it that some truths were uttered by the philosophers, in appearance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:26
verses.text: The divine apostle writes accordingly respecting us: "For now we see as through a glass;" knowing ourselves in it by reflection, and simultaneously contemplating, as we can, the efficient cause, from that, which, in us, is divine.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:27
verses.text: For it is said, "Having seen thy brother, thou hast seen thy God:" methinks that now the Saviour God is declared to us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:28
verses.text: But after the laying aside of the flesh, "face to face,"—then definitely and comprehensively, when the heart becomes pure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:29
verses.text: And by reflection and direct vision, those among the Greeks who have philosophized accurately, see God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:30
verses.text: For such, through our weakness, are our true views, as images are seen in the water, and as we see things through pellucid and transparent bodies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:31
verses.text: Excellently therefore Solomon says: "He who soweth righteousness, worketh faith".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:32
verses.text: "And there are those who, sewing their own, make increase".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:33
verses.text: And again: "Take care of the verdure on the plain, and thou shalt cut grass and gather ripe hay, that thou mayest have sheep for clothing".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:34
verses.text: You see how care must be taken for external clothing and for keeping.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:35
verses.text: "And thou shalt intelligently know the souls of thy flock".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:36
verses.text: "For when the Gentiles, which have not the law, do by nature the things contained in the law, these, having not the law, are a law unto themselves; uncircumcision observing the precepts of the law," according to the apostle, both before the law and before the advent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:37
verses.text: As if making comparison of those addicted to philosophy with those called heretics, the Word most clearly says: "Better is a friend that is near, than a brother that dwelleth afar off".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:38
verses.text: "And he who relies on falsehoods, feeds on the winds, and pursues winged birds".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:39
verses.text: I do not think that philosophy directly declares the Word, although in many instances philosophy attempts and persuasively teaches us probable arguments; but it assails the sects.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:40
verses.text: Accordingly it is added: "For he hath forsaken the ways of his own vineyard, and wandered in the tracks of his own husbandry".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:41
verses.text: Such are the sects which deserted the primitive Church.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:42
verses.text: Now he who has fallen into heresy passes through an arid wilderness, abandoning the only true God, destitute of God, seeking waterless water, reaching an uninhabited and thirsty land, collecting sterility with his hands.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:43
verses.text: And those destitute of prudence, that is, those involved in heresies, "I enjoin," remarks Wisdom, saying, "Touch sweetly stolen bread and the sweet water of theft;" the Scripture manifestly applying the terms bread and water to nothing else but to those heresies, which employ bread and water in the oblation, not according to the canon of the Church.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:44
verses.text: For there are those who celebrate the Eucharist with mere water.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:45
verses.text: "But begone, stay not in her place:" place is the synagogue, not the Church.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:46
verses.text: He calls it by the equivocal name, place.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:47
verses.text: Then He subjoins: "For so shalt thou pass through the water of another;" reckoning heretical baptism not proper and true water.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 17:48
verses.text: "And thou shalt pass over another's river," that rushes along and sweeps down to the sea; into which he is cast who, having diverged from the stability which is according to truth, rushes back into the heathenish and tumultous waves of life.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:1
verses.text: Chapter 20—In What Respect Philosophy Contributes to the Comprehension of Divine Truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:2
verses.text: As many men drawing down the ship, cannot be called many causes, but one cause consisting of many;—for each individual by himself is not the cause of the ship being drawn, but along with the rest;—so also philosophy, being the search for truth, contributes to the comprehension of truth; not as being the cause of comprehension, but a cause along with other things, and co-operator; perhaps also a joint cause.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:3
verses.text: And as the several virtues are causes of the happiness of one individual; and as both the sun, and the fire, and the bath, and clothing are of one getting warm: so while truth is one, many things contribute to its investigation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:4
verses.text: But its discovery is by the Son.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:5
verses.text: If then we consider, virtue is, in power, one.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:6
verses.text: But it is the case, that when exhibited in some things, it is called prudence, in others temperance, and in others manliness or righteousness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:7
verses.text: By the same analogy, while truth is one, in geometry there is the truth of geometry; in music, that of music; and in the right philosophy, there will be Hellenic truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:8
verses.text: But that is the only authentic truth, unassailable, in which we are instructed by the Son of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:9
verses.text: In the same way we say, that the drachma being one and the same, when given to the shipmaster, is called the fare; to the tax-gatherer, tax; to the landlord, rent; to the teacher, fees; to the seller, an earnest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:10
verses.text: And each, whether it be virtue or truth, called by the same name, is the cause of its own peculiar effect alone; and from the blending of them arises a happy life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:11
verses.text: For we are not made happy by names alone, when we say that a good life is happiness, and that the man who is adorned in his soul with virtue is happy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:12
verses.text: But if philosophy contributes remotely to the discovery of truth, by reaching, by diverse essays, after the knowledge which touches close on the truth, the knowledge possessed by us, it aids him who aims at grasping it, in accordance with the Word, to apprehend knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:13
verses.text: But the Hellenic truth is distinct from that held by us (although it has got the same name), both in respect of extent of knowledge, certainly of demonstration, divine power, and the like.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:14
verses.text: For we are taught of God, being instructed in the truly "sacred letters" by the Son of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:15
verses.text: Whence those, to whom we refer, influence souls not in the way we do, but by different teaching.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:16
verses.text: And if, for the sake of those who are fond of fault-finding, we must draw a distinction, by saying that philosophy is a concurrent and cooperating cause of true apprehension, being the search for truth, then we shall avow it to be a preparatory training for the enlightened man (τοῦ γνωστικοῦ); not assigning as the cause that which is but the joint-cause; nor as the upholding cause, what is merely co-operative; nor giving to philosophy the place of a sine quâ non.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:17
verses.text: Since almost all of us, without training in arts and sciences, and the Hellenic philosophy, and some even without learning at all, through the influence of a philosophy divine and barbarous, and by power, have through faith received the word concerning God, trained by self-operating wisdom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:18
verses.text: But that which acts in conjunction with something else, being of itself incapable of operating by itself, we describe as co-operating and concausing, and say that it becomes a cause only in virtue of its being a joint-cause, and receives the name of cause only in respect of its concurring with something else, but that it cannot by itself produce the right effect.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:19
verses.text: Although at one time philosophy justified the Greeks, not conducting them to that entire righteousness to which it is ascertained to cooperate, as the first and second flight of steps help you in your ascent to the upper room, and the grammarian helps the philosopher.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:20
verses.text: Not as if by its abstraction, the perfect Word would be rendered incomplete, or truth perish; since also sight, and hearing, and the voice contribute to truth, but it is the mind which is the appropriate faculty for knowing it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:21
verses.text: But of those things which co-operate, some contribute a greater amount of power; some, a less.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:22
verses.text: Perspicuity accordingly aids in the communication of truth, and logic in preventing us from falling under the heresies by which we are assailed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:23
verses.text: But the teaching, which is according to the Saviour, is complete in itself and without defect, being "the power and wisdom of God;" and the Hellenic philosophy does not, by its approach, make the truth more powerful; but rendering powerless the assault of sophistry against it, and frustrating the treacherous plots laid against the truth, is said to be the proper "fence and wall of the vineyard".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:24
verses.text: And the truth which is according to faith is as necessary for life as bread; while the preparatory discipline is like sauce and sweetmeats.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:25
verses.text: "At the end of the dinner, the dessert is pleasant," according to the Theban Pindar.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:26
verses.text: And the Scripture has expressly said, "The innocent will become wiser by understanding, and the wise will receive knowledge".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:27
verses.text: "And he that speaketh of himself," saith the Lord, "seeketh his own glory; but He that seeketh His glory that sent Him is true, and there is no unrighteousness in Him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:28
verses.text: On the other hand, therefore, he who appropriates what belongs to the barbarians, and vaunts it is his own, does wrong, increasing his own glory, and falsifying the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:29
verses.text: It is such an one that is by Scripture called a "thief".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:30
verses.text: It is therefore said, "Son, be not a liar; for falsehood leads to theft".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:31
verses.text: Nevertheless the thief possesses really, what he has possessed himself of dishonestly, whether it be gold, or silver, or speech, or dogma.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 18:32
verses.text: The ideas, then, which they have stolen, and which are partially true, they know by conjecture and necessary logical deduction: on becoming disciples, therefore, they will know them with intelligent apprehension.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:1
verses.text: Chapter 21—The Jewish Institutions and Laws of Far Higher Antiquity Than the Philosophy of the Greeks.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:2
verses.text: On the plagiarizing of the dogmas of the philosophers from the Hebrews, we shall treat a little afterwards.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:3
verses.text: But first, as due order demands, we must now speak of the epoch of Moses, by which the philosophy of the Hebrews will be demonstrated beyond all contradiction to be the most ancient of all wisdom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:4
verses.text: This has been discussed with accuracy by Tatian in his book To the Greeks, and by Cassian in the first book of his Exegetics.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:5
verses.text: Nevertheless our commentary demands that we too should run over what has been said on the point.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:6
verses.text: Apion, then, the grammarian, surnamed Pleistonices, in the fourth book of The Egyptian Histories, although of so hostile a disposition towards the Hebrews, being by race an Egyptian, as to compose a work against the Jews, when referring to Amosis king of the Egyptians, and his exploits, adduces, as a witness, Ptolemy of Mendes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:7
verses.text: And his remarks are to the following effect: Amosis, who lived in the time of the Argive Inachus, overthrew Athyria, as Ptolemy of Mendes relates in his Chronology.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:8
verses.text: Now this Ptolemy was a priest; and setting forth the deeds of the Egyptian kings in three entire books, he says, that the exodus of the Jews from Egypt, under the conduct of Moses, took place while Amosis was king of Egypt.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:9
verses.text: Whence it is seen that Moses flourished in the time of Inachus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:10
verses.text: And of the Hellenic states, the most ancient is the Argolic, I mean that which took its rise from Inachus, as Dionysius of Halicarnassus teaches in his Times.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:11
verses.text: And younger by forty generations than it was Attica, founded by Cecrops, who was an aboriginal of double race, as Tatian expressly says; and Arcadia, founded by Pelasgus, younger too by nine generations; and he, too, is said to have been an aboriginal.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:12
verses.text: And more recent than this last by fifty-two generations, was Pthiotis, founded by Deucalion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:13
verses.text: And from the time of Inachus to the Trojan war twenty generations or more are reckoned; let us say, four hundred years and more.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:14
verses.text: And if Ctesias says that the Assyrian power is many years older than the Greek, the exodus of Moses from Egypt will appear to have taken place in the forty-second year of the Assyrian empire, in the thirty-second year of the reign of Belochus, in the time of Amosis the Egyptian, and of Inachus the Argive.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:15
verses.text: And in Greece, in the time of Phoroneus, who succeeded Inachus, the flood of Ogyges occurred; and monarchy subsisted in Sicyon first in the person of aegialeus, then of Europs, then of Telches; in Crete, in the person of Cres.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:16
verses.text: For Acusilaus says that Phoroneus was the first man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:17
verses.text: Whence, too, the author of Phoronis said that he was "the father of mortal men".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:18
verses.text: Thence Plato in the Timoeus, following Acusilaus, writes: "And wishing to draw them out into a discussion respecting antiquities, he said that he ventured to speak of the most remote antiquities of this city respecting Phoroneus, called the first man, and Niobe, and what happened after the deluge".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:19
verses.text: And in the time of Phorbus lived Actaeus, from whom is derived Actaia, Attica; and in the time of Triopas lived Prometheus, and Atlas, and Epimetheus, and Cecrops of double race, and Ino.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:20
verses.text: And in the time of Crotopus occurred the burning of Phaëthon, and the deluge of Deucalion; and in the time of Sthenelus, the reign of Amphictyon, and the arrival of Danaus in the Peloponnesus; and trader Dardanus happened the building of Dardania, whom, says Homer,  "First cloud-compelling Zeus begat,"—  and the transmigration from Crete into Phoenicia.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:21
verses.text: And in the time of Lynceus took place the abduction of Proserpine, and the dedication of the sacred enclosure in Eleusis, and the husbandry of Triptolemus, and the arrival of Cadmus in Thebes, and the reign of Minos.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:22
verses.text: And in the time of Proetus the war of Eumolpus with the Athenians took place; and in the time of Acrisius, the removal of Pelops from Phrygia, the arrival of Ion at Athens; and the second Cecrops appeared, and the exploits of Perseus and Dionysus took place, and Orpheus and Musaeus lived.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:23
verses.text: And in the eighteenth year of the reign of Agamemnon, Troy was taken, in the first year of the reign of Demophon the son of Theseus at Athens, on the twelfth day  of the month Thargelion, as Dionysius the Argive says; but aegias and Dercylus, in the third book, say that it was on the eighth day of the last division of the month Panemus; Hellanicus says that it was on the twelfth of the month Thargelion; and some of the authors of the Attica say that it was on the eighth of the last division of the month in the last year of Menestheus, at full moon.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:24
verses.text: "It was midnight,"  says the author of the Little Iliad,  "And the moon shone clear".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:25
verses.text: Others say, it took place on the same day of Scirophorion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:26
verses.text: But Theseus, the rival of Hercules, is older by a generation than the Trojan war.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:27
verses.text: Accordingly Tlepolemus, a son of Hercules, is mentioned by Homer, as having served at Troy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:28
verses.text: Moses, then, is shown to have preceded the deification of Dionysus six hundred and four years, if he was deified in the thirty-second year of the reign of Perseus, as Apollodorus says in his Chronology.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:29
verses.text: From Bacchus to Hercules and the chiefs that sailed with Jason in the ship Argo, are comprised sixty-three years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:30
verses.text: aesculapius and the Dioscuri sailed with them, as Apollonius Rhodius testifies in his Argonautics.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:31
verses.text: And from the reign of Hercules, in Argos, to the deification of Hercules and of aesculapius, are comprised thirty-eight years, according to Apollodorus the chronologist; from this to the deification of Castor and Pollux, fifty-three years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:32
verses.text: And at this time Troy was taken.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:33
verses.text: And if we may believe the poet Hesiod, let us hear him:—  "Then to Jove, Maia, Atlas' daughter, bore renowned Hermes, Herald of the immortals, having ascended the sacred couch.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:34
verses.text: And Semele, the daughter of Cadmus, too, bore an illustrious son, Dionysus, the joy-inspiring, when she mingled with him in love".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:35
verses.text: Cadmus, the father of Semele, came to Thebes in the time of Lynceus, and was the inventor of the Greek letters.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:36
verses.text: Triopas was a contemporary of Isis, in the seventh generation from Inachus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:37
verses.text: And Isis, who is the same as Io, is so called, it is said, from her going (ἰέναι) roaming over the whole earth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:38
verses.text: Her, Istrus, in his work on the migration of the Egyptians, calls the daughter of Prometheus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:39
verses.text: Prometheus lived in the time of Triopas, in the seventh generation after Moses.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:40
verses.text: So that Moses appears to have flourished even before the birth of men, according to the chronology of the Greeks.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:41
verses.text: Leon, who treated of the Egyptian divinities, says that Isis by the Greeks was called Ceres, who lived in the time of Lynceus, in the eleventh generation after Moses.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:42
verses.text: And Apis the king of Argos built Memphis, as Aristippus says in the first book of the Arcadica.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:43
verses.text: And Aristeas the Argive says that he was named Serapis, and that it is he that the Egyptians worship.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book I.2 19:44
verses.text: And Nymphodorus of Amphipolis, in the third book of the Institutions of Asia, says that the bull Apis, dead and laid in a coffin (σορός), was deposited in the temple of the god (δαίμονο&.
